Sometimes a user will perform an action: Sometimes a user will perform an action which could possibly be destructive or traditionally irreversible. Rather than present the user with a warning, apps should allow the user to undo the action for an appropriate amount of time. Some prime examples of when this behavior is useful are:
<strong>Closing an app</strong>. Rather: Cierre de una aplicación. En lugar de advertir al usuario, automáticamente guarde su trabajo y el estado de la aplicación, para que puedan regresar exactamente donde lo dejó. Vea Cierre.
<strong>Deleting an item</strong>. Inste: Eliminación de un elemento. En lugar de preguntar al usuario si está seguro, hacer que el elemento "desaparecer" de la app, pero proporcionan una forma fácil e intuitiva para deshacer la eliminación.
<strong>Sending an email</strong>. Rathe: Enviar un correo electrónico. En lugar de preguntar al usuario si desea enviar un correo electrónico, les permiten deshacer o editar el mensaje de un corto período de tiempo después de "enviar."
<strong>Editing a photo</strong>. Instea: Editar una foto. En lugar de preguntar al usuario si desea aplicar una edición de forma irreversible, permiteles deshacer la edición y mantener siempre una copia de seguridad del original.
This behavior should only as a last reso: This behavior should only as a last resort be implemented by providing a buffer time between when the app shows the user what happened and actually performing the action. To keep the experience responsive, the app should always look as if it performed the action as soon as the user initiates it.
This behavior strikes the best balance o: This behavior strikes the best balance of keeping out of the user's way while making sure they don't do something unintended. It's important to keep the undo action unobtrusive yet simple and intuitive; a common way of doing so is by using an info bar, though other methods may also be appropriate.
